16. **Shipping and Containers**
   
   Mention any changes which you recall in the packaging and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

   Breakfast: Porridge, toast tea, maybe jam
   Dinner: Potatoes, maybe brown chicken or Puck
   Supper: maybe Pancakes, brown sugar syrup
   Bread & Butter, Saskatoon's Tea

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

   ...............1882

   Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

   Father, mother, Mary, William H. Donaldson, and uncle Alex MacKellar lived with us.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   Yes, we were sometimes very near starvation, with dry years and little money, but we always had wood and water on our own homestead, and lots of wild fruit, like Saskatoon's Raspberries, Strawberries, etc., got a great amount milled for winter, and always grew our own Potatoes and garden stuff; sometimes not very good crops, some years very dry.

18. Tell me all you can about the first Christmas dinner in Stanton Township

1882. We had a very nice dinner at Povesh's.

We then had a very nice dinner at Povesh's.

19. Tell me about your childhood experiences. What was life like?

I was very young when my parents moved to Stanton Township. We lived in a small house with my parents and two sisters. We had a garden and raised vegetables. We also had a cow and a pig. We always had enough food to eat and we never went hungry.
20. Notice any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today. Baking was all homemade, both baked at our Bread. Sometimes for the neighbor bachelors, and we sometimes eat things like the Pig and for Greens etc., that we do not use now.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). As I can remember, by 1875 most of the foods could be got at the Regina store which was run by the name of Jennings & Son. During all the early years, we sometimes got hampers of food and clothing from our friends in the East which helped a lot. In 1892, a cyclone came and took the roof and some logs of our log house, but none of us was hurt, we had to build anew house, a frame one this time.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in western Canada. I was not born till 1885. So most these answers are from the older ones of the Hinneard family. My Brother Will stayed on the homestead till 1944; he is now in Regina.

Regina
